text: the classical m music was as is always
the case in middle class European Jewish
homes uh it was a um a requirement
everybody sort of played an instrument
my mother was an amateur pianist and the
interesting part was that she was a
physician uh a very distinguished
physician and uh she lost her hearing
through a very strange disease where she
lost hearing on both sides uh a disease
that Jonathan Swift had called menier
and it destroys the inner ear so you
lose not only volume but pitch and when
I was a little boy I have no real memory
of my mother ever hearing so she lost
her hearing gradually and fits and
starts and the thing that was most
tragic it seemed to me as a child was
that she was no longer able to play so I
think that was a kind of psychological
motivator for me uh to study music so
they were very encouraging and um I
started out in the piano then switched
to the
violin well we started out in sort of a
very sort of ignorant context that is to
say my parents knowing nobody uh through
you know some recommendation through
other igrs we ended up with an igra
piano teacher and then I ended up uh
with uh a violin teacher again through
recommendations and finally I was lucky
um when I was an adolescent um my
grandparents lived in Mexico City and so
I spent the Summers there and there was
an igra German Austrian violin teacher
uh Herbert ferish who actually set me
straight and through him I was then
recommended to my major teacher Roman
totenberg very distinguished violist
who's alive today at
99 uh who fantastic violence and
fantastic teacher so I studied with him
for seven years but then during my
adolesence I already thought I wanted to
be either a composer or a
conductor so I tried my hand at
composing and uh I didn't write music
that I found memorable myself I was more
interested in other people's music so I
um then got interested in in doing
conducting and then when I was in
college uh I began to study and do
conducting
